 COMPLIANCE QUESTIONAIRE FOR BRD

- Credit application preparation which is currently manually prepared by RMs to be replaced with an AI driven solution.

- The solution shall be for both the New to Bank (NTBs) as well as Existing to Bank (ETBs).

- The AI solution will be linked to read the below identified internal systems of the bank to provide an output:

 Please list key business processes within the bank impacted by the proposed document:

- OPCRM

- Phoenix

- Credit Lens

- Shared drives

- WCAS

 Background

 Process Improvement:

- Increased efficiency resulting from reduction in time for an RM to prepare a Credit application.
- Streamlined workflow reducing the need for manual intervention, allowing RMs/Credit managers to focus on more complex and value-added activities.

 Performance improvement:

- Cost savings both on account of Operational Costs as well as Resource allocation.
- Faster processing times.

__data__.text: BRD_Project Merlin_Submission1

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

 3. INTRODUCTION

 3.1. Objectives, Background and Drivers

The primary objective of this Business Requirement Document (BRD) is to outline the requirements and specifications necessary to automate the credit application preparation process. The automation aims to enhance efficiency, accuracy, and consistency in the preparation of credit applications, thereby reducing manual errors, improving processing times, and supporting better decision-making. This initiative aligns with our broader goal of leveraging technology to streamline operations and deliver superior service to our clients.

The current credit application preparation process is predominantly manual, involving multiple steps and stakeholders. This labor-intensive process is prone to errors, delays, and inconsistencies, which can negatively impact customer satisfaction and operational efficiency. With the increasing volume of credit applications and the need for faster turnaround times, it has become imperative to adopt an automated solution.

Automation of the credit application preparation process will not only address these challenges but also ensure compliance with existing regulatory requirements related to the creation of Credit Applications, enhance data accuracy, and provide a scalable solution for future growth. By implementing this automated system, we aim to create a seamless and efficient workflow that supports our strategic business objectives and fosters a culture of continuous improvement.

 3.1.1 Project Overview

In summary, Project Merlin will deliver the following:

 Phase I

1. Enable the read of financial ratios, generated by Credit Lens
2. Apply credit rule based triggers to those ratios.
3. Based on the triggers, generate questions about the financials (that the RM is expected to address prior to submission).
4. Accept an additional upload of client based documents providing internal qualitative information including a bureau report and Enable the read of those documents.
5. Provide a list of prompts that the RM will then input into the tool (along with the information in #3 above).
6. Generate an industry background, an industry sector performance/current state analysis, company background (including shareholding information), company business model, a justification for the credit facility, and a list of risks associated with the credit facility (all where applicable).
- The solution will gather information from a closed container inference layer which will contain the web sources which are to be read. These include Bloomberg, MEED, Tomson Reuters, etc.
- The solution will be integrated with internal systems that will allow information on the customer (e.g. historical communication, covenant status, limit utilization, etc.) to be read to generate the response

 Phase II

1. Integrate the output from #6, above, into the WCAS tool (when ready) to serve as an editable field and for the purposes of credit application submission via workflow.

Note: the output will be in the form of free text and will not incorporate a prepopulated credit proposal in the current document layout.

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

By integrating these capabilities, the project aims to significantly improve decision-making processes and operational efficiency within the credit proposal framework.

 3.1.2 Project Background

Currently, the bank employs a manual (MS Word-based) credit approval format, which can be a cumbersome and complex task, fraught with numerous challenges that can impact the efficiency and accuracy of the process. It is susceptible to various errors, omissions, and duplications. The process necessitates manual copying and pasting of information, as well as time-consuming descriptions and distillations of the Business Model, Financial Situation, Ownership Structure, Current Collateral, and numerous other data points.

Some of the primary challenges associated with manual credit application preparation include:

- Time-Consuming Processes - Manual preparation involves gathering, verifying, and processing data, which slows down the application approval timeline. This can lead to delays and frustration.
- Data Accuracy and Consistency - Human errors in manual data entry and document review can result in inaccuracies, leading to incorrect credit decisions.
- Complex Documentation Requirements - Manually gathering and organizing required documents is cumbersome and increases the likelihood of missing or outdated information.
- Limited Scalability - Manual processes are not easily scalable and can lead to bottlenecks during peak periods.
- High Operational Costs - Manual preparation is labor-intensive and costly, with significant human resources required.
- Security and Confidentiality Concerns - Handling sensitive information manually raises security and confidentiality concerns.
- Difficulty in Tracking and Auditing - Manual processes make tracking and auditing progress challenging. Automated solutions improve transparency and accountability.

The project has identified two primary focus areas essential to addressing the current challenges faced by CBD. These focus areas aim to streamline processes, enhance efficiency, and improve the overall quality of financial analysis and credit ratings:

- Manual Information Gathering - The process of collecting the required information is predominantly manual. Audited financial statements submitted by clients are entered manually into Moody’s Credit Lens by the relationship management team, consuming approximately 40-60 minutes per financial year. This duration extends for larger groups with multiple borrowers, further diminishing the time available for business development or more valuable tasks.
- Complexity in Preparing Credit Requests - Due to the complexity of the information provided and the requirements of the approval process, the preparation of summaries, recommendations, and justifications for credit requests is highly time-consuming. This complexity adds to the overall workload and delays the credit approval process.

 3.1.3 Project Drivers

| ---------- | -- | - |

__data__.text:
3.1.4 Project Objectives

To ensure a seamless and efficient credit approval process, the proposed solution should use Generative AI to create a credit proposal, which will be reviewed by underwriters for loan approval. In doing so, the solution will address critical areas to ensure accurate and efficient financial evaluations.

 3.1.4.1 Embedding Credit Risk Triggers in Credit Application Creation

The proposed embedding of Credit Risk Triggers early in Credit Application Creation aims to proactively identify potential risks, enabling CBD to make more informed decisions and mitigate losses before they occur. By integrating these triggers at the outset, CBD can streamline the application creation process, reducing the time and resources spent on evaluating high-risk applicants. This early incorporation also enhances the accuracy of credit assessments, ensuring that only applicants with a favorable risk profile proceed further. Additionally, it fosters a more transparent and efficient workflow, as automated risk triggers can help guide the RMs in asking the right questions early on, allowing for immediate corrective actions.

The ambition is to overlay the financial ratios and Credit Risk Rating provided by Moody’s Credit Lens with triggers identified and defined by Credit Risk. The AI Solution should subsequently prompt the RMs to investigate these specific triggers and provide clarification, i.e. uploaded answers, as part of the workflow in the AI Solution.

The embedding of these triggers should allow for an incremental approach, starting with simple thresholds and triggers that would be enriched and refined gradually (exact list of triggers and thresholds to be defined during Design Phase and captured in Functional Specification Document).

 3.1.4.2 Populating a Draft Credit Application

Generative AI will streamline the credit application process by efficiently populating templates with essential details such as shareholding structure, industry overview, company background, relevant news, and business model descriptions. It will source accurate data from public web platforms, financial statements, and internal systems, adhering to the specifications outlined in the credit application master template and the Excel sheets in Appendices ID#1 and ID#2.

 3.1.4.2.1 Information Gathering and Presentation

The solution will use AI to extract and organize data, integrating with Credit Lens to collect financial ratios, and assess credit risk ratings. It will structure this information into the credit application format while parsing scanned documents and retrieving data as needed.

 3.1.4.2.2 Data Sources

__data__.text:
Business Requirement Document (BRD)

The solution will gather information from a variety of sources, ensuring comprehensive and accurate data collection. The sources include the following:

- Trusted Public Web Information: Covering a pre-defined repository of information, providing access to a wide array of data including up-to-date news, market trends, competitor analysis, and other valuable insights. Detailed list of websites to be defined during the Functional Scope Document Phase. No third-party subscription-based APIs will be used.
- Financial Statements, Valuations, RAROC, Risk Ratings through Credit Lens: Detailed financial documents providing insights into financial health, risk-adjusted return on capital (RAROC), and overall risk assessments.
- Documentation from Client: This encompasses company profile, Ultimate Beneficial Owner (UBO) details, management personnel details, contract copies, list of suppliers/customers, invoice copies, meeting notes, recordings, and proposed Term Sheets provided by the client, offering specific details and agreements pertinent to the project.
- CBD Policy Repository: A collection of Credit Risk Policies segmented by country and category, along with the Operational Risk Management Policy and Compliance policies, ensuring alignment with internal and regulatory guidelines.
- Internal Systems (Shard Drives, OPCRM, Phoenix, WCAS): Information retrieved from all the internal systems, which houses important internal data and communications pertaining to the customer, historical credit data (approvals/declines), one-off memos, limit utilization trends, profitability reports, delinquency reports, etc.
- CB UAE Bureau Reports: Reports from the Central Bank of UAE, providing detailed and performance of the borrowing history of the client across various financial institutions in UAE.

Given that this solution will be implemented for both NTBs and ETBs, the table below provides a snapshot of the various data sources that need to be linked with the proposed AI solution:

__data__.text:
3.1.4.2.3 User Input

Users will have an interface to enter customer details (RIM number, Trade License number, company/group name, etc.) and upload relevant files. An additional chatbot will allow them to run specific queries about the client, which can be included in the output.

 3.1.4.3 Conduct an Analysis and Provide Justification for the Loan

The comprehensive analysis conducted by the AI model will focus on evaluating the financial health of a company through detailed financial ratio analysis, comparing these metrics with industry benchmarks, and assessing the viability of the business model. Key financial ratios, including liquidity, profitability, leverage, and efficiency ratios, will be meticulously analyzed to provide quantitative insights into the company's operational efficiency and

BRD_Project Merlin_Submission1

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

stability. This analysis will help determine the company’s ability to meet its financial obligations and sustain its operations effectively.

Additionally, the AI model will compare the company's metrics with industry benchmarks to highlight its relative performance within the sector. This comparison will identify strengths, areas for improvement, and the company's competitive position. By evaluating market share, competitive advantages, and the overall industry landscape, the assessment will provide valuable insights into the company's market dynamics and its potential for growth.

Finally, the AI model will assess the viability of the company, thereby analyzing revenue streams, cost structures, value propositions, customer segments, and key resources and partnerships. These factors will help determine the sustainability and robustness of the company's financial performance. The comprehensive analysis will culminate in a well-substantiated justification for the loan proposal, incorporating insights into the company's financial stability, market position, and growth potential, thereby supporting informed credit decision making.

 3.2. Project Scope

 3.2.1 In Scope

The scope of Merlin is focused on automating the generation of the credit application pack for both new-to-bank and existing-to-bank clients. This automation aims to enhance efficiency and accuracy in decision-making. The credit application will be based on the systems highlighted under the "system used" swim lane in the figure below. Further details of all systems and data sources have been provided in Section 3.1.4.2.2 of this document.

1. Banking segments in scope are WBG Credit, Credit Middle Office, Institutional Banking and Corporate Banking.

 2. WBG processes in scope include:

- a. Customer credit risk rating process.
- b. Credit application write up process.

 3. Information points and details for decision making which should be covered in the credit application include the information points included in Appendices Section 2.

 3.2.2 Out of Scope

- The scope does not include any other steps in the process and does not include any activities related to the Credit Note assessment or creation (outside of the application of credit defined triggers and the generation of questions as a first level credit review).
- No third-party services or APIs are to be used for this source type. AI tool should support public websites scrapping.

BRD_Project Merlin_Submission1

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

- Integrations to allow for additional information points and sources other than the ones currently used, are out of scope.
- Exposing the application externally or making application accessible from mobile devices (mobile phones / tablets).

 3.3. Assumptions, Constraints and Risks

 3.3.1 Assumptions

- Technical ability of a partner to create a model that will develop this AI use-case.
- Integration with relevant repositories of information (CBUAE, Moody’s Credit Lens,) can leverage existing integrations and licensing.

The WCAS Upgrade Project and the future development efforts under Project Merlin Phase II are expected to converge, enabling alignment of objectives, and ensuring seamless integration.

 3.3.2 Constraints

- Cost approvals based on quotation received from external vendors.

 3.3.3 Risks

- Model hallucinations that will formulate justifications for a credit proposal that are not accurate. The compensating controls are described in the Non-Functional Requirements.

__data__.text:
Merlin Version 2 (Integration with WCAS Upgrade)

 4.2. Gaps Identification

Gaps and pain points are outlined in Section 3 “Introduction”.

 5. BUSINESS REQUIREMENTS

 5.1. Functional Requirements

The AI-enabled solution should utilize the information sources outlined in section 3.1.3.2.2 to automatically populate the Credit Application Template, replacing the manual steps previously performed by the RM. This will streamline the process, improve efficiency, and ensure consistency in the preparation of Credit Applications.

Below are some of the functional requirements identified to enable this:

 5.1.1 Overall Use Case

- User Interface:
- The RM should have a user-friendly interface to upload and share relevant documents, notes, and recordings that allow users to interact with the credit proposal solution, provide feedback, and make edits to the outcome as needed.
- The solution will ingest the output from EvalueServe’s Spreadsmart Solution and Moody’s Credit Lens and prompt the RM for Credit Risk Triggers.
- Solution should display the resulting triggers and thresholds breaches, RM to investigate with the client and provide justification for each of the breaches.
- Functional Workflow:

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

 Document Ingestion

- The RM uploads relevant documents, notes, and recordings via the interface.
- The solution processes these inputs to extract pertinent data for the Credit Application.

 Data Sourcing and Population

- The solution sources Financial Ratios and Credit Risk Rating from Moody’s Credit Lens and applies Credit Risk Triggers and Thresholds.

 Cross-Referencing

- The solution cross-references client-provided information with public and trusted web sources (data sources listed in section 3.1.3.2.2).
- Ensures data accuracy and completeness through validation.

 Integration with Internal Systems

- For existing clients, the solution retrieves additional information from Phoenix, OPCRM, WCAS, and other identified systems (as detailed in section 4.2).
- Integrates this information into the Credit Application template.

 CBUAE Report Access

- The solution automatically accesses and integrates CBUAE reports (https://10.15.15.15/) relevant to the client.

 Draft Credit Application Generation

- Mapping of the various data sets as detailed above with the Credit Application template as per Appendices ID#2.
- Populates the Credit Application for the client.
- The solution should provide a UI for the RM to review, adjust and finalize the prompts and credit application output as necessary.
- The document provided by the solution will be reviewed and adjusted by the RM and will be manually uploaded to WCAS when the RM is satisfied.
- The format for the Credit Application Generation should not follow a fixed format with tables and data without context. Instead, the Credit Application Generation should follow a principle of providing a clear and easy-to-understand story in the following three key sections:
1. Trends and Triggers highlighted following the Automated Financial Spreading
2. Financial Overview, Industry Analysis, Ownership structure
3. Section for the RM to address any investigations required with the client.
- The information included in that story should still contain and/or consider all the pieces of information as defined in Appendices ID#2. Additionally, the story generated by the Credit Application Generation Module cannot be overly optimistic but should be calibrated to be realistic and equally weigh both negative and positive aspects.
- The AI Solution should be guided by the current template guides used in the current Credit Application Template – a compilation has been provided in the appendices ID#5. Static data fields components should remain the same and be populated by pulling data from previous versions and underlying systems. The Credit Application templates provided in the appendices should be used as an indicative reference for the target data objects and information required for the credit application form.

Business Requirement Document (BRD)

 5.1.3 Audit Trail and Tracking of Adjustments to Model Output

- The solution and its output should clearly indicate what specific prompts have been used, including what documentation and sources have been used for what was generated.
- The Solution and its output should clearly indicate what has been created by the AI Model, what changes the RM has made, what additional prompts have been used, and what has been prepared by the RM without involvement from the Solution.

 5.1.4 Access Control Requirements

- The RM should only be able to query the solution about the specific case, i.e. Client/RIM.
- The RM should only be able to query the solution within office premises on the office systems.
- For ETB cases the RMs should only be able to query the AI solution about their own accounts.

 5.1.5 AI Model Training and Customization

To train the AI model, including the required customizations, 20 examples of manually prepared Credit Applications by the RM, along with the supporting documentation used to create them, will be provided to the vendor.

 5.1.7 Data Requirements (Mandatory)

- Detailed Data Sources per information point has been mapped in appendices ID#2.
- Trusted Public Web Information Sources to be defined and documented as part of the project execution in collaboration with RMs and their typical uses.

 5.1.8 Post Version 1.0 Considerations – Alignment with WCAS Upgrade Project

- The Solution is expected to, post deployment of Phase I, integrate with the WCAS Upgrade Project.
- The expectation is that the solution will be aligned with WCAS, thereby supporting the initial creation of the credit application before being taken through the improved workflow development in the WCAS Upgrade Project. The word document output from the Project Merlin Solution can be consumed directly by the future WCAS Upgrade Solution.

 5.2 Non-Functional Requirements

The solution is expected to handle at a minimum the following the volumes:

- Anticipated Volumes: Current Credit Application annual volumes (for NTBs and ETBs) are ~1,800 per year and with a growing client base, we can expect this number to increase to 4,000 per year within the next five years.
- Average files set size per Credit Application generation – 100 Mbs.
- Number of users - 200.
- Maximum number of linked business objects within a single application:
- Maximum Counterparties – 50
- Maximum Number of Limits – 300

5.3. Key Testing Scenarios

Including but not limited to:

- Test for performance / errors / lags / hangups and response times.
- Evaluate the accuracy of the AI solution's thresholds and triggers using the output ratios and credit risk ratings provided by Moody’s Credit Lens.
- Test for correctness of data whether data (rating and financial data) is being fetched from Credit Lens for Borrowers and Guarantors.
- Test whether output is aligned with current CA, CA Summary and Term Sheet format.
- Test whether application-generation function in the AI Solution is working.
- The testing is expected to be completed by selected individuals within the Coverage Teams, TBG Lending, and WBG Credit Risk.

 6. APPENDICES

The table assesses the impact of a proposed change in a process or system across various areas such as regulatory requirements, financial crime, systems and data, customer impact, and internal framework. It includes questions to determine if the change involves regulatory mandates, affects customer data, alters transaction types, impacts compliance systems, involves data sharing, or deviates from current policies.,
with the following columns:
- Impact: None
- Questions: None
- Yes: None
- No: None

| # | Impact             | Questions                                                                                                                                                                                                          | Yes | No |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1 | REGULATORY         | Has there been a regulatory requirement mandating the proposed change in process/system?                                                                                                                           | X   |    |
|   |                    | Is there any known regulation applicable to the proposed change in process/system?                                                                                                                                 | X   |    |
|   |                    | Does the proposed change result in adding or changing any customer data fields, e.g. KYC related fields, in any of the channels and/or core systems?                                                               | X   |    |
|   |                    | Does the proposed change result in adding new customer segments/types or reclassifying existing customer segments/types, e.g. RIM class codes, business segments etc., in any of the channels and/or core systems? | X   |    |
| 2 | FINANCIAL CRIME    | Does the proposed change result in adding new transactions code/type or changing existing transaction type/codes in any of the channels and/or core systems?                                                       | X   |    |
|   |                    | Does the proposed change result in workflow/process change which may impact existing compliance systems, i.e. Customer Risk Scoring, Transaction monitoring, Name and Payment screening?                           | X   |    |
|   |                    | Does the proposed change result in changes to the way transactions are posted in the core systems, which may impact existing compliance systems, i.e. Transaction monitoring and Payment screening?                | X   |    |
|   |                    | Does the proposed change in process/system involve sharing of bank or personal customer data with any third parties?                                                                                               | X   |    |
| 3 | SYSTEMS AND DATA   | Does the proposed change in process/system involve storing of bank or personal customer data outside of the bank?                                                                                                  | X   |    |
| 4 | CUSTOMER           | Is there any customer impact (whether direct or indirect) on account of the proposed change in process/system?                                                                                                     | X   |    |
|   |                    | If the update pertains to a new product or service, have the preliminary approvals been sought in line with risk assessment framework/NPA policy of the bank?                                                      | X   |    |
| 5 | INTERNAL FRAMEWORK | Does the proposed change in process/system suggest/imply any deviations from current applicable policy/procedure of the bank?                                                                                      | X   |    |

__data__.text:
This table outlines various non-functional requirements (NFRs) for an application, including performance, recovery, availability, data retention, security, and data protection measures.,
with the following columns:
- Req#: None
- Priority: None
- Parent/child: None
- Description: None

| Req#    | Priority | Parent/child                                                 | Description                                                                                                                                                                                          |
|---|---|---|---|
| NFR-001 |          |                                                              | The application should provide reliable UI response not breaching 2 sec in average. User actions triggering real-time data retrieve from other systems should not take longer than 5 sec on average. |
| NFR-002 |          |                                                              | RPO: 30 Minutes                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| NFR-003 |          |                                                              | RTO: 8 hours                                                                                                                                                                                         |
| NFR-004 |          | Uptime and availability:                                     | Application should be available to users 6 days a week (Monday – Saturday), 6 a.m. to 12 p.m.                                                                                                        |
| NFR-005 |          | Data Retention requirements and Data Archiving requirements: | Data captured in the application should be stored perpetually. The outcome from the AI Solution should be archived after 10 years.                                                                   |
| NFR-006 |          | Authentication and Authorization requirements:               | SSO, MFA                                                                                                                                                                                             |
| NFR-007 |          | RBAC Requirements:                                           | Requirements in terms of users access to: Credit Applications / Files & Attachments / Generated CA output files is defined in Functional Requirements Section. The rest RBAC should stay unchanged.  |
| NFR-008 |          |                                                              | Sensitive data should be masked or anonymized in non-production environments to prevent exposure during testing or development.                                                                      |
